import matplotlib as mpl
import seaborn as sns
%matplotlib inline
source.2cd4410e:
# we have totla 45 row in data 
# we replace date by time(1,2,3....45) 
total=df.Date.count()
time = pd.DataFrame([*range(1,total+1, 1)])
print(time[:5])
source.3f63eef0:
#Create linear regression object
reg = linear_model.LinearRegression()
reg.fit(time,df.Case)
source.09cf0277:
# here we use index number of date
case=reg.predict([[46]])
print(case)
source.46b413c5:
# now we comapare our prediction with actual data 
case=reg.predict(time)
print(case)
source.bf2c8463:
%matplotlib inline
plt.rcParams["figure.figsize"] = (20,10)
plt.plot_date(df.Date,df.Case,color='red')
plt.xlabel('Date')
plt.ylabel('Case')
plt.plot(case,color='blue')
plt.gcf().autofmt_xdate()

# Dataset
* i taking data from amc(Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation) website.
* Data contains two columns Date and Case
* it shows date wise  total cases in ahmedabad
source.05ac0aaf:
# Introduction
* **when will covid end ? we cannot say but we can predicate**
* in this notebook i use linear regression to predict covid-19 cases in ahmedabad city.
* you can use https://www.kaggle.com/sudhirnl7/linear-regression-tutorial this notebook to learn more about linear regression
